Introduction

Crying is the infant's primary mode of communication, with the duration varying widely but generally lasting <3 hours/day.  Infantile colic is a self-limited disorder characterized by excessive, unexplained crying in an otherwise healthy infant age <3 months.  Physical examination and growth parameters are typically normal, but colic often causes significant parental distress, and management focuses on caregiver support.

Epidemiology



Colic affects 10%-40% of infants globally, with higher proportions in resource-rich regions.  Factors associated with a higher incidence of colic include maternal smoking during pregnancy and maternal anxiety or depression.  There is no difference in incidence between male and female or breastfed and formula-fed infants.

Pathogenesis



The cause of colic is unknown but likely multifactorial and related to gastrointestinal and psychosocial factors.  Potential gastrointestinal contributors include immature gut motility and digestion, excess intestinal gas (eg, swallowing of air during feeds or crying), and altered gut microbiota.  Psychosocial factors include parental stress and anxiety affecting the perception of and response to crying, as well as infant hypersensitivity to environmental stimuli.

Clinical presentation



Colic manifests with excessive crying â‰¥3 hours/day for â‰¥3 days/week in an otherwise healthy infant age <3 months; onset is most commonly in infants age 2-3 weeks.  Crying generally occurs around the same time of the day (usually the evening), and parents often have difficulty consoling the infant during this time.  The crying often causes significant parental frustration and anxiety.



Episodes are often described as paroxysmal with a distinct beginning and endpoint of fussiness, and caregivers often report a louder, higher-pitched quality of crying compared to consolable periods at other times of day.  Some infants may have associated stiffening of the arms, drawing up of the legs, and arching of the back.



Physical examination and growth parameters are normal, reflecting appropriate growth in weight, length, and head circumference.

Differential diagnosis



Colic is a diagnosis of exclusion and must be differentiated from underlying medical conditions.  These conditions are usually associated with a variable crying pattern, history beyond crying (eg, fever, emesis, bloody stools, poor weight gain), or abnormal examination findings (

  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease:  Infants can have irritability and back-arching; these symptoms typically occur after feeding, not necessarily around the same time of day.  Spitting up is also typical, and feeding refusal and poor weight gain can occur in severe cases.
  • Intussusception (
    figure 1
    ):  Telescoping of one bowel portion into another presents with recurrent, 15- to 20-minute bouts of severe abdominal pain, often with the legs drawn into the abdomen.  Classic presentation is in patients age 6-36 months.  Vomiting (sometimes bilious) is common, and bloody stools occur with prolonged intussusception.
  • Infection:  Infection includes urinary tract infection, acute otitis media (
    figure 2
    ), meningitis, and septic arthritis (
    figure 3
    ).
  • Testicular/ovarian torsion:  Acute onset of irritability can be caused by testicular (
    figure 4
    ) or ovarian (
    figure 5
    ) torsion.  Swelling and tenderness of the scrotum are typical in male patients, whereas acute abdominal pain is expected in female patients.
  • Nonaccidental trauma (NAT) (
    figure 6
    ):  In cases of NAT, caregivers may seek medical attention for inconsolability, and concerning findings include bruising, asymmetric extremity movements (long bone fractures), or retinal hemorrhage and a bulging fontanelle (abusive head trauma (
    figure 7
    )).

Evaluation



Initial evaluation of any infant with excessive crying involves a thorough history that focuses on the timeline of crying (eg, acute vs chronic), as well as physical examination findings that may point to a specific cause (eg, tympanic membrane bulging in acute otitis media, asymmetric movements in septic arthritis or NAT).  Features that warrant evaluation with complete blood count, urinalysis, abdominal imaging, and/or neuroimaging may include fever, bilious emesis, bloody stools, poor weight gain, and abnormal physical examination findings.

Diagnosis



Colic is a diagnosis of exclusion based on the following findings:



  • Typical crying pattern (ie, â‰¥3 hours/day for no apparent reason â‰¥3 days/week in an otherwise healthy infant age <3 months).
  • Normal physical examination (including growth parameters).

Prognosis and management



Symptoms of colic peak at age 6 weeks and gradually improve until resolution by age 4 months.



Initial management includes providing caregivers with reassurance and support to help manage both parental distress and the patient's symptoms, including the following:



  • Review of soothing techniques, such as using a pacifier; holding, rocking, or swaddling the baby; and minimizing environmental stimuli (eg, dark room, white noise).  The use of swings, carriers, and strollers can also be calming and allows parents to rest from active soothing.
  • Adjustment of feeding techniques (eg, upright position in bottle-fed babies, frequent burping) to help reduce air swallowing.
  • Education regarding the natural course of colic, which is benign and self-limited, while encouraging the expansion of support networks (eg, lactation guidance) and screening for postpartum depression and anxiety.  Direct acknowledgment of caregiver frustration and exhaustion also provides support.

Summary



Colic is a diagnosis of exclusion characterized by crying for no apparent reason for â‰¥3 hours/day for â‰¥3 days/week in an otherwise healthy infant age <3 months.  Management includes parental reassurance and support with review of soothing techniques.  The natural course of colic is spontaneous resolution by age 4 months.
